measured_by: child-friendly decision-making task adapted from Cockburn et al., 2022
justification: “Participants ages 8–27 years … completed a child-friendly decision-making task adapted from one used in a prior adult study (Cockburn et al., 2022).” This task was used to observe how often they explored versus exploited reward options.

measured_by: novel vs familiar option choices within the adapted exploration task
justification: The task “contained two hiding spots that participants had encountered in previous blocks and one novel hiding spot… In this way, the task dissociated sensory novelty…,” allowing choice data to quantify each participant’s tendency to pick novel options.

measured_by: uncertainty manipulation (variance of reward probabilities) in the exploration task
justification: The same task varied “reward uncertainty,” defined as “the variance in the distributions of rewards,” letting the authors model how strongly participants avoided high-uncertainty options.

measured_by: surprise memory test of creatures’ favorite hiding spots
justification: “After the exploration task, participants completed a surprise memory test in which they were shown each of the ten creatures … and asked to select its favorite hiding spot.” Memory accuracy scores served as the measure.

measured_by: Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence – Vocabulary and Matrix Reasoning subtests
justification: “Participants were administered the vocabulary and matrix reasoning subtests of the Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (Wechsler, 2011).” These standardized subtests provided an IQ estimate.
